page.title: 09 Trethevy Quoit
page.content:
Trethevy Quoit is a Bronze Age burial chamber at Trethevystone, 1.5 miles NE of St. Cleer. It was built about 1500 B.C. It consists of seven stones making two chambers, with a stone across the top that weighs 18 tons. The stones were dragged from Caradon Hill, 3 miles away. The capstone has a hole in it at one end. The spaces between the large stones were filled with little rocks, and then covered by a huge mound of earth. The mound has now gone, leaving only the stones. The Quoit held about 20 bodies.
The custom of burial mounds originated in the Mediterranean countries in the Stone Age.
